facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 744 of 1967 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated 2nd March 1965 of the Kerala High Court in A.S. No. 216 of 1961

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 744 of 1967. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated the 2nd March 1965, of the Kerala High Court at Ernakulam, in A. S. No. 216 of 1961. Krishnamoorthy Iyer, Annamma Allexander, S. K. Mehta, R. Nagaraja, Qamaruddin and Vinod Dhawan, for the appellant.

facts.text: Kerala High Court dismissed an appeal against the judgment and decree of the Subordinate Court of Havelikkara

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by JAGANMOHAN REDDY, J.-This appeal is by special leave against the judgment and decree of the High Court of Kerala which dismissed an appeal against the judgment and decree of the Subordinate Court of Havelikkara.

facts.text: Appellant filed a suit on October 24, 1942 for recovery of Rs. 2 lakhs and interest from State of Travancore (now State of Kerala) and three others

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had filed a suit on October 24, 1942, for the recovery of Rs. 2 lakhs and interest thereon from the date of suit and for costs originally against the State of Travancore now the State of Kerala-the respondent-and three others who however were not made parties in the appeal before the High Court.

facts.text: Plaintiff appellant was wrongfully dispossessed from 160 acres of Cherikkal land along with improvements appropriated by the State without right

anchor.surface_text: It has alleged in the plaint that the plaintiff appellant was wrongfully dispossessed from 160 acres of land along with the improvements which had been effected by him and as the State had appropriated those improvements without any right or title thereto he claimed the value of those improvements.

facts.text: Appellant and his father occupied 160 acres of Cherikkal land and made improvements including planting coconut trees, arecanut palms, peppervines, rubber-trees, jack trees and constructing bungalow, huts, wells in bona fide belief lands belonged to Koodalvalli Illom

anchor.surface_text: It was the appellants case that he had been in occupation of the said 160 acres of Cherikkal land unregistered dry lands in hilly tracts about which and the adjoining lands there was a dispute as to whether the same belonged to a jenmi family known as Koodalvalli Illom--hereinafter called the Illom--or to the Government of the erstwhile Travancore State. The appellants father and the appellant had occupied these lands, made improvement thereon by planting coconut trees, arecanut palms, peppervines, rubber-trees, jack trees, other trees, and by constructing bungalow, huts, wells etc. in the bona fide belief that the lands belonged to the Illom.

facts.text: Dispute between Koodalvalli Illom and Travancore State over the lands from about 1848

anchor.surface_text: This practice it seems, was also current in respect of lands belonging to the, Government be-fore the Travancore Land Conservancy Act 4 of 1091 24-7-1916 hereinafter called the Act . It is the case of the appellant that even, after the Act was passed, unauthorised occupants of land belonging to the Government who had made improvements therein had, under the rules made both under the Act and the Land Assignment Act a pre- ferential claim over others for getting kuthakapattom or assignment of the property in their possession. It may be mentioned that in respect of the 160 acres of land of the Illom which were occupied by the appellants father and the appellant, there was a dispute between the Illom and the Travancore State from about 1848.

facts.text: Appellant applied to Conservator of Forests for registration of lands, rejected on June 14, 1919 (Ext. A)

anchor.surface_text: While this dispute was pending it appears the appellant applied to the Conservator of Forests for registration of the lands in his name, but the application was rejected on June 14, 1919 stating that the land applied for cannot be registered Ext. A .

facts.text: Illom instituted suit O.S. No. 126 of 1096 (January 1918) in District Court Quilon for declaration of title, dismissed on 28-6-1109 (February 10, 1934), appeal dismissed September 27, 1943

anchor.surface_text: While the application for registration was pending, the dispute between the Illom and the State of Travancore had reached a stage when the Illom had to institute a suit O. S. No. No. 126 of 1096 January 1918 in the District Court at Quilon for a declaration of its title to those properties. In that suit the appellant, after his application for registration was rejected, sought to get himself impleaded, but that application also was rejected. Thereafter the suit filed by the Illom was dismissed on 28-6-1109 February 10, 1934 . An appeal against it was dismissed on September 27, 1943.

facts.text: Government initiated ejectment proceedings against appellant in C. Case No. 112 of 1100 (1925 A.D.)

anchor.surface_text: It may here be mentioned that while the suit of the Illom i.e. O.S. No. 126 of 1096 M.E. was pending in the District Court, Quilon, the Government of Travancore had initiated proceedings in ejectment against the appellant by C. Case No. 112 of 1100 1925 A.D. .

facts.text: Appellant filed suit O.S. 156 of 1103 M.E. (1927-28 A.D.) in District Court Quilon against respondent for title to 160 acres and adjoining lands

anchor.surface_text: As the suit of the illom had been finally disposed of and the title of the Illom to the lands was not established, the appellant apprehending that he might be ejected in the above L.C. Case filed a suit No. O.S. 156 of 1103 M.E. 1927-28 A.D. in the District Court at Quilon against the respondent to establish his right and title to the said 160 acres and in the adjoining Cherikkal lands in his possession.

facts.text: In O.S. 156, injunction prayed for 100 acres rejected; Civil Miscellaneous Appeal No. 206 of 1110 M.E. (1934-35 A.D.) filed, Commissioner report (Ext. CC) listed improvements including bungalow, houses, rubber estate, trees

anchor.surface_text: In that suit an injunction was prayed for in respect of 100 acres of the property involved in the suit, but the prayer was rejected. Against that order a Civil Miscellaneous Appeal No. 206 of 1110 M.E. 1934-35 A.D. was filed in the High Court of Travancore. The High Court issued a commission for inspecting the properties and the Commissioner in his report part 13 of Ext. CC set out the improvements made by the appellant on the lands which comprised of a bungalow in which the appellant was residing, a number of small houses. a rubbers state, and a large number of other valuable trees like jack trees, mango trees, coconut trees etc.

facts.text: Order passed for dispossessing appellant on July 24, 1939 (Ext. VI) in L.C. Case No. 112 of 1100 M.E.; dispossessed and possession given to second defendant Nair Service Society Ltd. in August 1939

anchor.surface_text: It appears that as there was no injunction restraining his dispossession in L.C. Case No. 112 of 11,00 M.E. an order was passed for dispossessing the appellant on July 24. 1939, Ext. VI. The appellant, pursuant to this order, was dispossessed from the lands and possession of these lands was given to the second defendant Nair Service Society Ltd. in August 1939.

facts.text: Suit filed against Government on October 24, 1942

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the suit out of which this appeal arises was filed against the Government on October 24, 1942.

facts.text: Respondent contended appellant encroached on suit lands, evicted in L.C. Case No. 112 of 1100 M.E., trespass recent origin, entry not in belief land belonged to Illom, improvements not by appellant but by other squatters, no notice of forfeiture served but order passed

anchor.surface_text: The respondent-State contended that the appellant encroached on the suit lands, that proceedings were taken against him in L.C. Case No. 112 of 11 00 M. E. and he was evicted in due course, that the trespass by the appellant was of recent origin, that the allegation that the entry was made in the belief that the land belonged to the Illom was false, that the Revenue and Forest Departments did not harass the appellant but they took steps for dispossessing him only in accordance with the law, that the Commissioners report was not correct in that all the improvements noted by the Commissioner were not made by the appellant but by other independent squatters, that after due notice an order of forfeiture had been passed in L.C. Case No. 112 of 1100 M.E. and the appellant was therefore not entitled to claim any value for improvements as it was his duty to remove any building before he was evicted.

facts.text: Trial Court decreed Rs. 3000 for value of appellant's bungalow, rest of claim dismissed

anchor.surface_text: Several issues were framed, but it is not necessary to refer to them except to say that the suit was decreed only for Rs. 3000/being the value of the appellants bungalow taken possession of by the respondent. The rest of the claim was dismissed.

facts.text: Trial Court found appellant's possession commenced close to 1100 M.E., not from 1030 M.E. as claimed

anchor.surface_text: it was observed by the Trial Court that though there is no specific evidence to show when exactly the possession of the appellant had commenced, the evidence however indicated that it must have started close to the year I 100 M. E. and that in any case the claim of the appellant that possession was from 1030 M.E. was not true

facts.text: No order of forfeiture passed under s.9 of the Act, conceded by Government Pleader

anchor.surface_text: With respect to the allegation that an order of forfeiture was not served on the appellant under s. 9 of the .Act, the Court observed that though the State had in its written statement contended that such an order had been passed, no order was produced in evidence and consequently it was conceded by the Government Pleader that no such order was passed.

facts.text: Supreme Court found appellant's possession commenced after 1919 registration rejection, not bona fide

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated that the finding that the possession of the appellant ,commenced after his application for registration was rejected in 1919, and the improvements, if any must have been effected only thereafter with full knowledge that the title to the lands was in dispute between the Illom and the Government, is unassailable.

facts.text: Trees not included in 'any crop or other product raised on the land' under s.9 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellant that the trees which are the subject-matter of the appeal should have been forfeited by an order passed under s. 9 of the Act and in the absence of such. an order his right to the value of those trees had to be adjudged and paid. to him was also negatived, as the Court held that the words any crop or other product raised on the land occuring in s. 9 of the Act would not include trees.

facts.text: No notice of forfeiture under s.9 given to appellant, conceded before Trial Court

anchor.surface_text: It was conceded before the Trial Court and no attempt was made to establish anything to the contrary before the High Court that no notice of forfeiture as required under s. 9 was given to the appellant.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed by Supreme Court with no order as to costs but court fee recovered from appellant

anchor.surface_text: In the view we have taken, the appeal has no substance and is accordingly dismissed with no order as to costs, but the court fee will be recovered from the appellant.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment
Travancore Land Conservancy Act 4 of 1091  24-7-1916   hereinafter called the Act .

anchor.surface_text: With respect to the allegation that an order of forfeiture was number served on the appellant under s. 9 of the .Act, the Court observed that though the State had in its written statement companytended that such an order had been passed, numberorder was produced in evidence and companysequently it was companyceded by the Government Pleader that numbersuch order was passed. In the circumstances the question that had to be companysidered was whether without an order of forfeiture being passed, the respondent companyld forfeit the improve- ments.

arguments.claim: Trespasser not entitled to compensation for trees under general law

anchor.surface_text: In its view these words take in what is familiarly known in law as emblements... compensation for trees which are to be dealt with under the general law cannot be decreed in favour of a mere trespasser who had no rights therein.

arguments.claim: Position of trespasser not better than tenant, no compensation for trees

anchor.surface_text: Another reason for disallowing the compensation for trees given by the High Court was that the position of a trespasser-whether he be a mere trespasser or a trespasser under a bona fide claim of title--cannot be better than that of a tenant, and that if this is correct, then the appeal has to be dismissed on the short ground that there is no principle of law or equity which requires the payment of compensation in respect of trees

arguments.claim: No order of forfeiture under s.9, so entitled to compensation under general law

arguments.claim: Trespasser not entitled to compensation for improvements/trees under general law, even if intent to improve

arguments.claim: No notice of eviction required for trees as not in s.9, and point not properly raised
arguments.court_reasoning: Not pleaded clearly, no issue, plaint shows opportunity for movables

holdings.text: The finding that the possession of the appellant commenced after his application for registration was rejected in 1919, and the improvements, if any must have been effected only thereafter with full knowledge that the title to the lands was in dispute between the Illom and the Government, is unassailable.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated that the finding that the possession of the appellant ,commenced after his application for registration was rejected in 1919, and the improvements, if any must have been effected only thereafter with full knowledge that the title to the lands was in dispute between the Illom and the Government, is unassailable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms lower courts' findings based on appellant's conduct in applying for registration and impleadment, showing knowledge of government claim; possession post-Act prohibiting unauthorized occupation.

holdings.text: He cannot be said to be a bona fide trespasser particularly after he had applied to the Government for obtaining a registration in his name on the basis that it was Government land.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances he cannot be said to be a bona fide trespasser particularly after he had applied to the Government for obtaining .a registration in his name on the basis that it was Government land.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant's applications demonstrate awareness that land was government property, negating bona fide belief in private ownership.

holdings.text: Trees are not included within the meaning of other products raised on the land in s. 9 of the Act and there is, therefore, no obligation on the Government to give notice of forfeiture under that section.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation: 'other product raised on the land' qualified by 'crop', refers to emblements (annual products severed from soil); supported by dictionary definitions and precedent (Clark v Gaskarth).

holdings.text: Trees are not included within the meaning of s. 9, so as to entitle the appellant to a notice of forfeiture thereunder.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.9 covers crops/products like emblements, not trees attached to soil; eviction notice not required for trees.

holdings.text: Under the general law even a trespasser on the land, whether bona fide or not, is not entitled to compensation or damages for the improvements made by him on the land, such as trees.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No authority for proposition; dangerous policy to allow wrongful trespassers compensation; trespasser position not better than evicted tenant who gets no compensation for affixed improvements.

holdings.text: The position of a trespasser cannot be better than that of a lawful tenant who having lost his possession cannot claim compensation or damages for anything erected on the land or any improvements made therein.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy to tenant: no compensation for trees/affixed items post-eviction.

holdings.text: The appellant cannot now be permitted to raise this contention [no notice of eviction given under s.9] before us.
holdings.reasoning_summary: New point not pleaded in plaint, no issue framed in trial or appeal; contradicted by plaint averments implying opportunity to remove movables.

holdings.text: The appeal has no substance and is accordingly dismissed with no order as to costs, but the court fee will be recovered from the appellant.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative holdings reject all claims for compensation on trees/improvements.
